event.doc_name: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

extracted.value: Jay Treaty of 1794 (Article III) exempting Indigenous people from border duties

evidence.text: It is agreed that it shall at all Times be free ... to the Indians dwelling on either side of the said Boundary Line, freely to pass and repass by Land or Inland Navigation, into the respective Territories and Countries of the Two Parties on the Continent of America ... and freely to carry on trade and commerce with each other. ... Nor shall the Indians passing or repassing with their own proper Goods and Effects of whatever nature, pay for the same any Impost or Duty whatever.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

patch.value: Tariff Act of 1799 (Sections 104-105) exempting Indigenous people from tariffs

evidence.text:
SEC. 104. And be it further enacted, That for the purpose of conforming this act to certain stipulations contained in treaties made and ratified under the authority of the United States, it is hereby declared, that it shall at all times be free to British subjects, and also to the Indians dwelling on either side of the boundary line of the United States, as settled by the treaty of peace, freely to pass and repass, by land or inland navigation, into and from the territories of the United States, and to navigate all the lakes, rivers and waters thereof, and freely to carry on trade and commerce with the citizens of the United States:

SEC. 105. And be it further enacted, That no duty shall be levied or collected on the importation of peltries brought into the territories of the United States, nor on the proper goods and effects of whatever nature, of Indians passing, or repassing the boundary line aforesaid, unless the same be goods in bales or other large packages unusual among Indians, which shall not be considered as goods belonging bona fide to Indians, nor be entitled to the exemption from duty aforesaid.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

patch.value: Blackfeet Treaty of 1855 establishing tribal territory abutting Canada border

evidence.text: In October of 1855 the U.S. Government signed the Blackfeet Treaty with the Blackfoot Nation (Piegan, Blood, Blackfoot, and Gros Ventre), the Flathead Nation (Flathead – Salish, Upper Pend d’Oreille, Kootenai), and Nez Perce Indians.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

patch.value: Marias River massacre (1870) involving Piikani people

evidence.text: In January of 1870 American troops massacred over 200 Piikani people near the Marias River in present-day Montana. Piikani witnesses claimed the dead numbered about 220 people.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

patch.value: Treaty of Ghent (1814) affirming Jay Treaty rights for Indigenous people

evidence.text: The 1814 Treaty of Ghent affirmed the Jay Treaty recognition of rights, including the right to pass through the United States-Canada border and the right to take goods across the border duty-free, providing in Article IX that both nations agreed to 'restore to such Tribes or Nations respectively all the possessions, rights, and privileges which they may have enjoyed or been entitled to in one thousand eight hundred and eleven previous to such hostilities.'
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

patch.value: Oregon Treaty (1846) confirming 49th parallel border without limiting Indigenous rights

evidence.text: The Oregon Treaty of 1846 resolved disputes between the U.S. and Britain and confirmed the 49th parallel as the boundary but did not address or limit the trade and passage rights of Native Americans as set out in the Jay Treaty.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

patch.value: Treaty 7 (1877) signed by First Nations with Canadian government

evidence.text: In 1877 the First Nations signed Treaty 7 with the Canadian government. The First Nations negotiating the treaty understood the treaty to be primarily a peace treaty, allowing settlement and promoting peaceful cohabitation; it is agreed that none of the Indigenous nations involved in the treaty understood that the treaty was a surrender of land.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

patch.value: 1883 Tariff Act preserving Indigenous tariff exemption

evidence.text: The 1883 Tariff Act included substantially the same language of Section 105 of the 1799 Tariff Act: 'SEC. 2512.-That no duty shall be levied or collected on the importation of peltries brought into the Territories of the United States by Indians, nor on the proper goods and effects, of whatever nature, of Indians passing or repassing the boundary-line aforesaid, unless the same be goods in bales or other large packages unusual among Indians, which shall not be considered as goods belonging to Indians, nor be entitled to the exemption from duty aforesaid.'
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

patch.value: Buffalo Treaty (2014) revitalizing cross-border tribal relationships

evidence.text: In 2014, Tribes from Montana joined other First Nations in signing the Iinii Treaty or Buffalo Treaty, including: the Blackfeet Nation (American band), Assiniboine and Gros Ventre Tribes of Fort Belknap, Assiniboine and Dakota Tribes of Fort Peck, Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes (Coast and Interior Salish), and the Tsuut’ina Nation. The Treaty recognizes and revitalizes the Tribes relationship with the buffalo: 'It is our collective intention to recognize BUFFALO as a wild free-ranging animal and as an important part of the ecological system; to provide a safe space and environment across our historic homelands, on both sides of the United States and the Canadian border, so together WE can have our brother, the BUFFALO, lead us in nurturing our land, plants and other animals to once again realize THE BUFFALO WAYS for our future generations.'
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

patch.value: Tribal Border Crossing Parity Act (2024) addressing Jay Treaty protections

evidence.text: In 2024 Senator Steve Daines cosponsored the 'Tribal Border Crossing Parity Act,' to acknowledge protections under the Jay Treaty of 1794 and to eliminate the 50 percent blood quantum requirement for members of federally recognized tribes when exercising their treaty-protected right to cross between the U.S. and Canada freely.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

patch.value: Executive Orders 14193, 14197, 14231 and Proclamations 10896, 10895 (2025) imposing universal tariffs

evidence.text: First: Plaintiffs challenge the constitutionality of Executive Order 14193 (February 1, 2025 (Imposing Duties to Address the Flow of Illicit Drugs Across Our Northern Border)1, as amended by Section 3 of Executive Order 14197 (Progress on our Northern Border)2 and further amended by Executive Order 142313 of March 6, 2025 (Amendment to Duties To Address the Flow of Illicit Drugs Across Our Northern Border). ... Second: Plaintiffs challenge Proclamation 10896 (steel) and Proclamation 10895 (aluminum).4 These two Proclamations were issued February 10, 2025 and invoke authority under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962, as amended (19 U.S.C. 1862).
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

Nor shall the Indians passing or repassing with their own proper Goods and Effects of whatever nature, pay for the same any Impost or Duty whatever.

evidence.text: SEC. 105. And be it further enacted, That no duty shall be levied or collected on the importation of peltries brought into the territories of the United States, nor on the proper goods and effects, of whatever nature, of Indians passing, or repassing the boundary line aforesaid, unless the same be goods in bales or other large packages unusual among Indians, which shall not be considered as goods belonging bona fide to Indians, nor be entitled to the exemption from duty aforesaid.

add_extracted.value: Tariff Act of 1799 explicitly exempted Indigenous people from duties on goods crossing the border

evidence.text: On March 25, 2025, Plaintiff Jonathan St. Goddard had a wheel break on his tractor, and found the only available replacement part in Saskatchewan, across the border in Canada. St. Goddard paid $308 tariff on the part that was $1,252.89 (U.S. Dollars), increasing his costs for ranching substantially.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff Jonathan St. Goddard paid $308 tariff on a $1,252.89 tractor part from Canada

evidence.text: On February 1, 2025, three Executive Orders declared a national emergency due to increased immigration and fentanyl flows into the United States. Under the stated emergency, the Executive Orders imposed tariffs on goods from Canada, Mexico, and China.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Executive Order 14193 (Feb 1, 2025) imposed universal tariffs on goods from Canada, Mexico, and China under IEEPA

evidence.text: On December 24, 1814 the Treaty of Ghent was signed, restoring pre-war boundaries and marking the end of British support for Native American Indians. On February 17, 1815 the U.S. Senate unanimously approved Treaty of Ghent. The 1814 Treaty of Ghent affirmed the Jay Treaty recognition of rights, including the right to pass through the United States-Canada border and the right to take goods across the border duty-free.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Treaty of Ghent (1814) reaffirmed Jay Treaty rights for Indigenous people crossing borders
